tossups.answer: Calendars [or Julian calendar; or Gregorian calendar; or the Roman calendar]

parts: Name this scalar boson that gives mass to certain gauge bosons. Leon Lederman popularized the term “God particle” to refer to this particle.
The discovery of the Higgs boson filled in the last missing piece of this theory in particle physics. This theory classifies all elementary particles, which are often depicted in a colorful table.
This problem in the Standard Model has to do with the Higgs’ small mass, and why gravity is so much weaker than the other fundamental forces. One proposed solution to this problem is supersymmetry.

answers: The Heart is a Lonely Hunter
clock [accept A Clockwork Orange; accept Clock Without Hands]
parts: Name this novel, whose deaf-mute protagonist befriends Biff Brannon and Jake Blount. In this novel, John Singer kills himself after the death of Spiros Antonopoulos [“Spear-os An-ton-ah-pou-lows”].

Carson McCullers, the author of The Heart is a Lonely Hunter, titled her final novel about one of these devices “Without hands.” The “workings” of one of these devices describes an orange in the title of an Anthony Burgess novel.
In this Carson McCullers novel, Bernice takes care of the 12 year old tomboy Frankie Adams, who wishes to join her brother, Jarvis, on his honeymoon to Alaska.

answers: Kingdom of Italy [or Italia; or Italian Republic; or Repubblica Italiana]
Battle of Solferino [or the Battle of Solferino and San Martino]
parts: Name this man, who commanded the Red Shirts in the Expedition of the Thousand against the Spanish Bourbons while conquering Sicily.
Garibaldi was a leader in the Risorgimento, whose goal was the unification of this modern-day country. Victor Emmanuel II was crowned as this country’s first king in Rome.
After witnessing the carnage of this battle during the Risorgimento, Henri Dunant was inspired to give aid to the wounded and found the International Red Cross.

answers: AIDS [or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome; prompt on HIV or human immunodeficiency virus]
quilts [or AIDS quilt; or obvious equivalents]
parts: Name this disease, an epidemic of which started in the early 1980s.
In 1990, Haring’s name was added to an AIDS memorial of this medium started in 1985. Artist Faith Ringgold’s work chronicles her life in Harlem using this medium in works such as Tar Beach.
A Keith Haring painting is titled A Pile of Crowns for [this artist]. This Haitian-American artist was part of the graffiti duo SAMO with Al Diaz and eventually died of a heroin overdose.
Name this river that flows into the Mississippi River at Cairo [“kay-roh”], Illinois. Cities on this river include Louisville and Cincinnati.
This tributary of the Ohio river has a name meaning “falling banks” in the Unama language. It rises in the Allegheny Plateau and flows through the southwest of Pennsylvania.
The Monongahela and Allegheny Rivers merge to form the Ohio in this Pennsylvania city’s Point State Park. It is also home to the headquarters of H.J. Heinz Company and is called the “Steel City.”

answers: instant replay [or reasonable equivalents, such as action replay or video replay; prompt on a challenge]
parts: Name this service performed during the World Cup by VAR. Coaches in the NFL wishing to use this service throw a red flag onto the field.

Hawkeye’s technology was gradually adopted in tennis after several questionable calls in this player’s quarterfinal loss to Jennifer Capriati at the 2004 U.S. Open. This woman was again embroiled in controversy after she was docked a game against Naomi Osaka at the 2018 U.S. Open.
The first instant replay in Major League Baseball was used after a hit by this then-Yankee third baseman in 2008, upholding a home run call.

answers: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]
parts: Name this country, whose 1930’s muralism movement depicted historical figures like Miguel Hidalgo and was led the “big three,” including David Alfaro Siqueiros.

This other “big three” artist painted a series of frescoes showing the impact of Native Americans and European colonists on North America for Dartmouth College, titled The Epic of American Civilization.

This final member of “the big three” depicted his wife Frida Kahlo in part of a massive mural of The History of Mexico. This artist’s mural Man at the Crossroads was painted over due to its controversial depiction of Lenin.

answers: Zimbabwe [or Republic of Zimbabwe; do NOT accept or prompt on “Rhodesia”]
ZANU-PF [or the Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front]
parts: Name this leader, who violently confiscated the land of white farmers in the mid-2000s to redistribute it to the poor residents of his country. His recent opponents include Morgan Tsvangirai [“svan-gee-rye”].
Robert Mugabe was first Prime Minister and then President of this southern African nation. This country was known as Rhodesia when it was led by Ian Smith.
In 2017, this party sacked Robert Mugabe as its leader and appointed Vice President Emmerson M-nan-gag-wa in his place.

answers: A Good Man Is Hard to Find
parts: Name this character who notes that “it’s no pleasure in life” after shooting a woman in the chest three times.
The Misfit appears in this story about the family trip to Florida where their death is foreshadowed by the Grandmother’s mentioning of an article about the Misfit heading towards Florida.
This author’s Southern Gothic style and depiction of grotesque characters is exemplified in her short story “A Good Man is Hard to Find.”

answers: Arabidopsis thaliana [or Arabidopsis; or thale cress]
parts: Name these reproductive plant structures. The ABC model describes the development of whorls of petals in these structures.
The ABC model of flower development arose from study of gene expression in this model organism from the mustard family. This plant’s tiny genome was the first for a plant be fully sequenced.
The outermost whorl of the meristem of Arabidopsis is differentiated into these leaf-like protective structures with the expression of class A genes. These structures collectively form the calyx.

answers: carp [or Indian carp, or Asian carp, or grass carp, or silver carp, or common carp]
parts: Name this group of freshwater fish. Members of the family Cyprinidae, these fish include goldfish and koi.

Asian carp are harmful to the native species of this system of lakes and its tributaries because of the competition for room in the water and food. This system includes Lake Michigan and Lake Superior.
Other invasive species found in the Great Lakes are the quagga and zebra types of these animals. These bivalve molluscs include the family Mytilidae and Dressinidae.

answers: Worcester v, Georgia [prompt on Georgia alone]
parts: Name this Native American tribe. The Treaty of New Echota was signed on behalf of this tribe, whose written language was developed by Sequoyah.
This 1830 legislation forced the Cherokee out of Georgia, and many other Native American tribes out of the Southeast. The Trail of Tears occurred due to the implementation of this act.
This Supreme Court case saw Chief Justice John Marshall rule that only the federal government had the right to deal with Native American tribes.

answers: floods [or deluge; prompt on rain or storms]
female [or obvious equivalents, such as woman or girl]
parts: The first avatar of Vishnu, Matsya, took the form of a giant fish to save Manu from one of these cataclysmic events. In the Bible, Noah builds an ark to survive one of these events.
Vishnu’s seventh avatar, Rama, fought against this ten-headed Rakshasa king of Lanka who had abducted his wife, Sita.
Mohini was the only avatar of Vishnu to be this type of person. The water buffalo demon Mahishasura could only be killed by a person of this type, which Durga eventually did.

answers: shepherd [or “The Passionate Shepherd to His Love”]
parts: Name this eventual husband of Una, who is revealed to be Saint George in Canto X of the work in which he appears.
The Redcrosse Knight plays a central role in The Faerie Queene by this English poet who, along with Shakespeare and Petrarch, names a type of English sonnet.

Edmund Spenser wrote a poem titled for the “Calendar” of this profession. Christopher Marlowe wrote a poem about a “passionate” type of this figure who hopes to watch others of this profession feed their flocks while spending some time with his love.

answers: Jean-Paul Sartre [or Jean-Paul Charles Aymard Sartre]
parts: Marcel was an early example of the Christian variety of this school, one of whose earliest thinkers argued that “anxiety is the dizziness of freedom” in The Concept of Anxiety.
Marcel dreaded being associated with this other existentialist thinker, who wrote a work that described concepts such as “bad faith” and “radical freedom,” his Being and Nothingness.
Gabriel Marcel, Simone de Beauvoir, and Jean-Paul Sartre all wrote in this language, as did Franz Fanon, who was born in Martinique and wrote The Wretched of the Earth.

answers: Eilert Lovborg’s manuscript [accept, but do not otherwise reveal, the manuscript in Hedda Gabler]
parts: Name this object owned by Eilert Lovborg, which is burned by the title character. After burning this object, the title character suggests Lovborg commit suicide, which he does.
The title character of this play commits suicide herself after securing her husband George [“yur-gah”] Tesman’s position for the professorship by burning Lovborg’s manuscript.
This Norwegian playwright of Hedda Gabler wrote about Nora Helmer leaving her husband in the play A Doll’s House.
Name this Italian virtuoso, rumored to have made a deal with the devil. A movement from Schumann’s Carnaval named for this man is one of two that is not derived from the A.S.C.H. motif.
Paganini wrote a collection of 24 Caprices, renowned for their technical difficulty, for this highest string instrument, featuring multiple stops and various bowing techniques.
The 24th Caprice has provided material for a set of variations by both Brahms and this pianist, whose 18th variation inverts the theme and transposes it to D-flat Major.
Name this religion, one branch of which traces its lineage to the writings of a British civil servant named Gerald B. Gardner. A ritual black-handled knife in this religion is called an athame.
A religious movement named the “Ancient Order” of this word was established in 1781 in London, inspired by but with no connection to Celtic religious leaders of the same name.

Both Wicca and Druids are examples of Neo- or modern religions under this broader category. Christians used this word and heathen as pejoratives against these polytheistic or pantheistic nature-worshipping religions

answers: Catherine the Great [or Yekaterina Velikaya; or Catherine II; or Yekaterina Alekseyevna; or Sophie Friederike Auguste, Prinzessin von Anhalt-Zerbst; prompt on Catherine; prompt on Yekaterina]
Grigory Potemkin [“Pah-tem-kin,” or Grigori Aleksandrovich Potemkin-Tavricheski; or Potemkin Villages]
parts: Name this enlightened despot, who was put on the throne through a coup orchestrated by Grigori Orlov. This monarch also faced Pugachev’s [“Poo-gah-chev’s”] Rebellion.
Catherine the Great was the leader of this empire. Other tsars of this country included Michael, the founder of its Romanov dynasty.
This lover of Catherine the Great created namesake fake villages during one of Catherine’s visits to the Crimea.

answers: Josiah Gibbs [or Josiah Willard Gibbs; or Gibbs Free Energy; or Gibbs-Donnan Effect; or Gibbs-Donnan Equilibrium]
parts: Name this state, in which two systems maintain the same temperature. The zeroth law of thermodynamics shows how this property is transitive.
Another equilibrium, named for Donnan and this scientist, describes charged particles across a semipermeable membrane. This man names a “free energy” measuring the spontaneity of reactions.
Another equilibrium named for Schlenk describes halides of this element. Reacting this alkali earth metal with an alkyl halide creates strong nucleophiles useful in creating carbon-carbon bonds.
